text: Hi, I'm Nancy DiTomaso

from Rutgers Business School,
Newark and New Brunswick,
and it's great to be here.
This conference is an anecdote

to some of the issues I'd
like to raise with you.
And it also is very different
than most of the conversations
that we have when we talk about issues
of diversity, equity, and inclusion,

and I think that we
need to recognize that.
I'm going to show my age,

and I have a sense that
across the audience,

there will be some people who
don't actually remember any
of these events.
So I wanted to remind us
that almost to the day,
this is the 30-year anniversary
of what was called the Los Angeles Riots
that occurred, because Rodney King

was beaten nearly to death by
four white police officers,
and then they were acquitted
or not found guilty for that.

One of the things that made
it significant, of course,

was because it was one
of the first such events
that was recorded on video.
And that's one of the things
that made it easier to respond.
So after this near-death beating

by the police in Los
Angeles, it sparked a riot,

some called it, which
63 people were killed
and 2,000 were injured.
And Rodney King famously asked
after recovering from his injuries,
"Can't we all just get along?"

That event, of course, which
was a very unfortunate incident
had to do with police brutality,
mistreatment of an unarmed Black man.

But, of course, the
experience of Rodney King

was 25 years after the
Civil Rights movement,
and after the riots that took place
in '63, '64, up through about '68
that also many times were sparked
by police misconduct and mistreatment
of Black men and women across the country.
Some people called those rebellions,

but most of them were
sparked by police brutality
toward unarmed Black men and women.
And now 30 years later,
of course, in Minneapolis, Minnesota,
we have the killing by police
of another unarmed Black man

in broad daylight in the
streets on video tape
when George Floyd was executed.
And again, we saw massive protests
across the country, even around the world,

and thought of that
somehow as a seminal event
that was going to change everything.
And now we are a year or two after,

and already the memory of
it is beginning to fade,
and we're seeing very different responses.
So, between those two events

of Rodney King saying, "Can't
we all just get along?"

And George Floyd sparking
what we thought of
as a social justice movement,

we've seen inequality and
wealth and income has grown.

Political polarization has
become more pronounced.

There are global crises
with constant threats,
and in this environment, both companies
and countries are facing the challenges

of how people can get
along with each other,

especially as populations
have become more diverse

in their composition
with migrations of people
all over the world

from different races,
ethnicities, religions
on a grand scale.
And then in the context of this,

we see the seeds of a
new political movement
but it's in the context now

of a global pandemic,
a challenging economy,
global conflicts that threaten the future,
even more so now than before,
and a political environment
that is trying to make sure

that these kind of events do
not lead to any substantive
and major changes.
This is not just circumstantial.
This is a political struggle,
and it is a very determined one
to try to undermine the kinds of forces
that would make it possible for us
to raise the kinds of issues

that we have been talking about
all day today and tomorrow.
As many of you know,

across the country, not
only is it now illegal

in some states to talk about
any of these issues K to 12,
it's increasingly the case in some states
that you can't even talk about this
at the college level
without some kind of threat of punishment.
So in the context of these kinds of things
where democracy is being undermined,

we have right wing authoritarian
governments arising,

and the intent in many of
these efforts, essentially,

is to use the way that
we categorize each other,
and try to understand those differences
as ways to secure political reactions
that will intensify the conflict.

We can think about what
normally is reflected
in the research literature,
reflected in the corporate world,

in terms of what they
talk about as diversity,
equity, and inclusion.

And from my mind, there has
been far too much attention
to things like individual prejudice, bias,
thinking somehow that the problem

is that some people are racist
or sexist or homophobic,
and that the way to address these issues

is somehow to focus on the
bias against those people
as opposed to the bias for white men

who are the ones that are
in charge, and in power.
So I think we need a much broader vision.
The political environment we're in
is a contested terrain.
It's a power struggle,

and we need to keep in mind
that change does happen,
that it is possible to be transformative
but it is not something

that is either guaranteed
or that is fully understood.
We sometimes forget

that what we think of as
the secure institutions
of today disappear.

People in power don't necessarily
know what they're doing.

And they are afraid of
the mobilization of people

against the kinds of
injustice and inequality,

and part of our
responsibility is to make sure
that we address those kinds of issues.
Thank you.
